section.title: Limits at Infinity Tending to Zero
section.p: When using limit laws to establish limit values as x\to\infty or x\to-\infty, limit laws A1-A6 and R2 are still in play (when applied in a valid manner), but limit law R1 cannot be applied. (The reason limit law R1 cannot be applied is discussed in detail in through from .)

There is a new replacement law that can only be applied when x\to\infty or x\to-\infty; this is replacement law R3. Replacement law R3 essentially says that if the value of a function is increasing without any bound on how large it becomes or if the function is decreasing without any bound on how large its absolute value becomes, then the value of a constant divided by that function must be approaching zero. An analogy can be found in extremely poor party planning. Let's say that you plan to have a pizza party and you buy five pizzas. Suppose that as the hour of the party approaches more and more guests come in the doorin fact the guests never stop coming! Clearly as the number of guests continues to rise the amount of pizza each guest will receive quickly approaches zero (assuming the pizzas are equally divided among the guests).
